name: Averroes
ideology_notes: Strong rationalist interpreter of Aristotle; defended philosophy’s compatibility with Islam; held the ‘double-truth’ theory (truth of reason and truth of revelation can differ without contradiction); rejected personal immortality for a collective intellect
handedness_notes: No reliable contemporary portraits or accounts specify hand preference

name: Maimonides
ideology_notes: Leading medieval Jewish rationalist; sought to reconcile Aristotle with Torah; negative theology (God cannot be described positively); strong emphasis on reason as the path to understanding divine law (Guide for the Perplexed); viewed Torah as containing philosophical wisdom
handedness_notes: No surviving portraits or contemporary descriptions mention handedness; historical texts discuss left-handedness as a disqualification for priests but provide no info on Maimonides personally

name: Michel Foucault
ideology_notes: Explicitly atheist and anti-humanist; rejected universal truth claims and grand narratives; analyzed power/knowledge dynamics, discourse formation, and subjectivity; later engaged with ancient practices of self-care as ethical technologies, but without theistic commitments
handedness_notes: Photographs, archival footage, and lecture videos from 1960s–1980s consistently depict right-handed writing, gesturing, and handling objects

name: Al-Khwarizmi
ideology_notes: Devout Sunni Muslim in the Abbasid era; viewed mathematics as a divine science to reveal God's order in creation; works like Al-Jabr show no explicit theology but embody rationalist method within Islamic framework; no evidence of conflict between faith and reason
handedness_notes: No contemporary portraits, artifacts, or accounts from 9th century specify hand preference; historical records focus on intellectual output, not personal habits
sources_ideology: Al-Kitab al-mukhtasar fi hisab al-jabr wal-muqabala

name: Albert Einstein
ideology_notes: Rejected anthropomorphic God and organized religion; 'I believe in Spinoza's God, who reveals himself in the lawful harmony of the universe'; emphasized ethical humanism, cosmic religious feeling, and science as path to truth; cultural Jew but non-practicing
handedness_notes: Extensive photographic and film evidence from 1900s–1950s shows right-handed writing, violin playing (standard bow hold), and tool use
sources_ideology: The World As I See It (1934)

name: Archimedes
ideology_notes: Exemplar of pure deductive reasoning and empirical invention; no surviving theological texts; cultural context of Syracuse suggests conventional Greek polytheism (e.g., invocation of gods in 'Sand Reckoner'), but work is entirely secular and method-driven
handedness_notes: No contemporary portraits, artifacts, or accounts from 3rd century BCE indicate hand preference; historical records emphasize inventions over personal details

name: Aristotle
ideology_notes: Founder of formal logic and empirical natural philosophy; posited an eternal, unmoved mover as pure actuality and final cause (non-personal prime mover); integrated reason with teleological cosmology; influenced by Plato but emphasized observation and categorization
handedness_notes: No surviving contemporary depictions or accounts from 4th century BCE specify hand preference; focus of records is on teachings and writings

name: Avicenna
ideology_notes: Devout Twelver Shia Muslim; synthesized Aristotelian philosophy with Islamic theology; proved God's existence via the argument from necessary being; viewed reason and revelation as harmonious; emphasized intellectual emanation from the One
handedness_notes: No contemporary portraits or accounts from 10th–11th century Persia specify hand preference; biographical focus is on intellectual and medical achievements

name: Blaise Pascal
ideology_notes: Devout Catholic influenced by Jansenist rigor; emphasized faith over pure reason ('The heart has its reasons which reason knows not'); Pascal's Wager as probabilistic argument for belief; critiqued skepticism and libertinism while advancing scientific method
handedness_notes: 17th-century portraits (e.g., by Philippe de Champaigne) and engravings depict right-handed posture; no evidence of left-handedness in biographical accounts

name: Chien-Shiung Wu
ideology_notes: No recorded religious beliefs; raised in Confucian-influenced China but showed no theistic commitments; lifelong focus on empirical science and rational inquiry; described herself as a 'scientific person' without spiritual affiliations
handedness_notes: Numerous laboratory photographs and videos from the 1950s–1970s show her writing, operating equipment, and signing documents with right hand

name: Dante Alighieri
ideology_notes: Devout Catholic deeply influenced by Thomas Aquinas and scholasticism; The Divine Comedy integrates classical theism, Aristotelian reason, and Christian eschatology; viewed poetry as a vehicle for theological truth and moral philosophy
handedness_notes: No contemporary portraits or reliable accounts from 13th–14th century Italy specify hand preference; surviving illustrations are later medieval copies

name: David Hume
ideology_notes: Effectively atheist/agnostic in private; publicly skeptical to avoid persecution; critiqued religion as superstition in 'The Natural History of Religion'; rejected miracles, design arguments, and personal immortality; emphasized empirical observation over metaphysical speculation
handedness_notes: Contemporary portraits (e.g., by Allan Ramsay) and descriptions depict right-handed writing and gesturing; no evidence suggesting otherwise

name: Donna Haraway
ideology_notes: Explicitly non-religious; left Catholicism due to moral and doctrinal issues predating loss of belief; work critiques anthropocentrism and promotes situated knowledges, cyborg feminism, and materialist posthumanism without supernatural elements
handedness_notes: No mentions in biographies, interviews, or visual records specify hand preference

name: Euclid
ideology_notes: Ancient Greek mathematician from Hellenistic period; no surviving personal writings on religion; cultural context indicates conventional polytheism (e.g., worship of Olympian gods), but Elements is entirely secular, axiomatic, and deductive; viewed as exemplar of pure rationalism without theological overlay
handedness_notes: No contemporary accounts, portraits, or artifacts from 3rd century BCE specify hand preference; historical focus is solely on mathematical contributions

name: Francis Bacon
ideology_notes: Devout Anglican who viewed science as revealing God's book of nature; advocated inductive method over deductive rationalism; 'knowledge is power' as tool for dominion over creation; reconciled faith with empirical inquiry in Advancement of Learning
handedness_notes: No contemporary portraits or accounts from 16th–17th century specify hand preference; biographical focus is on writings and politics

name: Hannah Arendt
ideology_notes: Secular Jewish thinker who identified as agnostic; raised in non-religious family but attended Reform synagogue as child; critical of revealed religion and Christianity's ascetic tendencies; emphasized political action and human condition over theological frameworks
handedness_notes: No mentions in biographies, interviews, photographs, or scholarly accounts specify hand preference

name: Hippocrates
ideology_notes: Pioneered empirical, naturalistic approach to medicine rejecting supernatural causes for disease; cultural Greek polytheism (believed in gods but separated from medical practice); emphasized observation, prognosis, and rational ethics over religious divination
handedness_notes: No contemporary accounts, portraits, or artifacts from 5th century BCE specify hand preference; historical records focus on medical teachings

name: Homer
ideology_notes: Foundational figure in ancient Greek religion; epics depict anthropomorphic Olympian gods intervening in human affairs with human-like flaws and emotions; shaped Greek mythology, heroism, and worldview; religious orientation central to narrative structure
handedness_notes: Semi-legendary figure from 8th century BCE; no contemporary accounts, portraits, or artifacts exist to indicate hand preference

name: Lise Meitner
ideology_notes: Secular Jewish background; fled Nazi persecution due to Jewish heritage but showed no religious observance; emphasized empirical science and rationality; no evidence of theistic beliefs in writings or interviews
handedness_notes: Photographs from 1920s–1960s show right-handed writing, lab work, and gesturing; no contradictory evidence

name: Michelangelo
ideology_notes: Devout Catholic; deeply influenced by Christian theology and Savonarola's preaching; works like Sistine Chapel ceiling and Last Judgment reflect biblical narratives and divine inspiration; blended with Renaissance Neoplatonic humanism emphasizing ideal forms and the soul's ascent to God
handedness_notes: Self-portraits, anatomical drawings, and contemporary accounts depict right-handed tool use and drawing; chisel marks on sculptures consistent with right-hand dominance

name: Nelson Mandela
ideology_notes: Baptized Methodist Christian; drew on faith for moral guidance and forgiveness (e.g., Truth and Reconciliation Commission); public politics emphasized secular humanism, ubuntu (African communal ethics), and universal human rights over religious dogma
handedness_notes: Numerous photographs and videos from 1960s–2010s show right-handed writing, gesturing, and tool use (e.g., signing documents, saluting)

name: Noam Chomsky
ideology_notes: Atheist and rationalist; critiques religion as ideological tool for power; emphasizes empirical science, universal grammar, and libertarian socialism; Jewish cultural background but rejects theism and organized religion
handedness_notes: Photographs and lecture videos consistently show right-handed writing and gesturing

name: Pierre Bourdieu
ideology_notes: Analyzed religion as a social field of power relations and symbolic capital; personal beliefs secular and materialist, influenced by Marxist critique of ideology; no evidence of theistic commitments; treated religion sociologically without theological endorsement
handedness_notes: No biographical or visual evidence specifies personal hand preference; references to 'left/right hand' are metaphorical for state functions
sources_ideology: JSTOR article on sociology of religion

name: Plato
ideology_notes: Foundational rationalist emphasizing innate ideas, dialectic, and the Forms as eternal truths; theistic elements in divine craftsman (Demiurge) and soul's immortality, but prioritized reason over revelation; influenced Western philosophy's rational tradition
handedness_notes: Ancient figure (4th century BCE); speculative claims exist (some sources suggest right-handed, others left), but no reliable contemporary evidence; discussions in historical texts are philosophical, not biographical

name: Raphael
ideology_notes: Devout Catholic artist whose works like the Sistine Madonna and School of Athens blend Christian theology with Renaissance humanism; illustrated biblical narratives and divine love; viewed art as a means to embody religious beliefs and ideal forms
handedness_notes: Contemporary drawings and self-portraits depict right-handed posture; some lists claim left-handed but disputed by analysis of his works showing right-hand dominance

name: Richard Feynman
ideology_notes: Agnostic atheist who embraced uncertainty; science cannot disprove God but he preferred living without answers; critiqued religion as faith-based while respecting it; emphasized moral inspiration from religion but prioritized empirical doubt
handedness_notes: Photographs, videos, and biographical accounts show right-handed writing, bongo playing, and gesturing; no evidence of left-handedness despite physics discussions on symmetry
sources_ideology: The Pleasure of Finding Things Out

name: Rosalind Franklin
ideology_notes: Culturally Jewish but explicitly atheist; challenged family religious beliefs from youth; placed faith in empirical science and humanism ('bettering the world through knowledge'); rejected unseen religious doctrines in favor of replicable facts
handedness_notes: No biographical accounts, photographs, or records specify personal hand preference; searches yield only discussions of DNA helix chirality

name: Socrates
ideology_notes: Believed in divine beings and a daimonion (inner divine voice guiding ethics); emphasized piety, justice, and rational inquiry as service to the gods; rejected anthropomorphic myths but affirmed divine order; executed for 'impiety' yet defended religious devotion through philosophy
handedness_notes: Ancient figure (5th century BCE); no contemporary depictions or accounts specify hand preference; historical lists of left-handers do not include him

name: Thomas Kuhn
ideology_notes: Secular philosopher of science; no recorded religious beliefs; treated religion historically (e.g., as worldview in paradigm shifts) without personal endorsement; emphasized empirical, contextual analysis over universal truths or supernatural claims
handedness_notes: No biographical or visual evidence specifies hand preference; searches yield only professional biographies without personal details

name: Tim Berners-Lee
ideology_notes: Rejected Anglican upbringing as teenager; identifies as atheist with 'faith' in humanistic principles; later adopted Unitarian Universalism (non-theistic, reason-based) as parent; views web as ethical, open system influenced by UU values of interconnectedness and justice
handedness_notes: No specific mentions in biographies or interviews; searches focus on professional life without personal habit details

name: Ada Lovelace
ideology_notes: Viewed science and religion as intertwined ('Religion to me is science, and science is religion'); retained spiritual/mystical leanings (e.g., interest in mesmerism) despite rational mathematical work; did not fully retain orthodox Christian belief like her mother; saw herself as 'instrument for divine purposes'
handedness_notes: Listed among famous left-handers in historical compilations; no direct contemporary evidence but consistent with biographical analyses

name: Adam Smith
ideology_notes: Deist with Protestant influences; assumed God's existence and creation of valuable reality; viewed religion as natural confirming hopes/fears; praised Christian atonement but critiqued state religions for corrupting clergy; integrated moral sentiments with divine order
handedness_notes: No biographical or visual evidence specifies hand preference; searches yield only political left/right discussions

name: Al-Farabi
ideology_notes: Prominent Islamic Peripatetic philosopher; synthesized Aristotelian logic and metaphysics with Islamic theology; posited a hierarchical emanation from the One (God) through intellects; emphasized reason as path to divine knowledge and virtuous society
handedness_notes: No contemporary portraits or accounts from 9th–10th century Baghdad specify hand preference; biographical focus is intellectual

name: Alan Turing
ideology_notes: Atheist and materialist; rejected supernaturalism in favor of logical positivism and empirical science; no religious affiliations; focused on computability, AI, and moral questions through rational analysis
handedness_notes: Photographs and biographical accounts from 1930s–1950s show right-handed writing and gesturing; no contradictory evidence

name: Alexander Graham Bell
ideology_notes: Raised Presbyterian but evolved to agnostic with Unitarian leanings; attracted to non-dogmatic, tolerant theology emphasizing reason and humanism; no strong theistic commitments; focused on ethical progress through science and education
handedness_notes: Photographs and portraits (e.g., with Helen Keller) show right-handed gestures and manual alphabet use; no evidence of left-handedness

name: Barbara McClintock
ideology_notes: Little patience for organized religion; devoted life to empirical science and intuitive understanding of nature; described 'mysticism' as deep scientific empathy with living systems, not supernatural belief; rejected dogmatic comforts in favor of observable truths
handedness_notes: No biographical accounts, photographs, or records specify hand preference; searches yield only general discussions of handedness genetics

name: Baruch Spinoza
ideology_notes: Pantheist who equated God with Nature (Deus sive Natura); rejected anthropomorphic God, miracles, and personal immortality; naturalistic ethics grounded in reason; excommunicated from Judaism for heretical views; advocated religious tolerance as public indifference
handedness_notes: No contemporary accounts or portraits specify hand preference; biographical focus is on philosophy, not personal habits

name: Bernhard Riemann
ideology_notes: Devout Lutheran Christian; son of a Lutheran pastor; viewed faith as most important aspect of life; integrated religious piety with mathematical work; initially studied theology before mathematics; believed in God's hand in creation and order
handedness_notes: No biographical accounts, portraits, or records specify hand preference; historical focus is on mathematical contributions
